value: Diagnosis of ankle sprain typically results from an acute injury, often due to sudden twisting or rolling of the ankle, leading to partial or complete tears of the ligaments.
Diagnosis of ankle sprain is very commonly seen in both primary and secondary care settings and across all types of real-world healthcare data.
25 to 50 (Individuals typically present with ankle sprains during young adulthood and middle age, often due to sports injuries or everyday accidents.)
45% to 55% (The sex distribution is roughly equal, with a slight male predominance in some studies due to increased participation in high-risk activities.)
99% to 100% (Mortality is extremely low as ankle sprains are generally not life-threatening.)
0-5% with diagnosis of prostate cancer, 5-15% with new user of morphine

For those with diagnosis of prostate cancer, ankle sprain would typically occur randomly before or after diagnosis, whilst for new users of morphine, the morphine use would typically start at the same time or soon after the ankle sprain (within 1-30 days).

hypertension, obesity, diabetes, osteoarthritis, depression, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, anxiety, back pain, osteoporosis (These comorbidities are commonly seen due to the broad age range and the general population affected by ankle sprains.)

ankle pain, ankle swelling, ankle instability, ankle stiffness, ankle bruising, limited ankle range of motion, ankle tenderness, difficulty weight bearing, ankle deformity, ankle redness (These signs and symptoms are directly related to the injury and inflammation caused by the sprain.)

ibuprofen, paracetamol, naproxen, diclofenac, codeine, morphine, aspirin, celecoxib, meloxicam, tramadol (These medications are commonly used for pain management and reducing inflammation associated with ankle sprains.)
Prostate cancer is a malignancy of the prostate gland, often driven by androgen stimulation.
Prostate cancer is commonly diagnosed, particularly in older males, and cases can be identified in various real-world healthcare data, including primary care and hospital settings.
65 to 75 (Prostate cancer typically presents in individuals aged 65 to 75 years old.)
99% to 100% (Almost all diagnosis_of_prostate_cancer individuals are male.)

75% to 98% (The five-year survival rate for prostate cancer is generally high, but varies depending on the stage at diagnosis, with approximately 98% for localised disease but only 30% for metastatic disease.)
0-1% with diagnosis_of_ankle_sprain, 1-5% with new_user_of_morphine.

For people in diagnosis_of_prostate_cancer who also appear in new_user_of_morphine they typically would enter diagnosis_of_prostate_cancer first, some time before entering new_user_of_morphine (perhaps a matter of months to years) and for diagnosis_of_ankle_sprain there is no clear ordering as the overlap is largely due to chance alone.

Hypertension, Hyperlipidaemia, Type 2 Diabetes, Obesity, Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia, Erectile Dysfunction, Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms, Chronic Kidney Disease, Depression, Osteoarthritis. (These comorbidities are commonly seen in older males.)

Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms, Erectile Dysfunction, Nocturia, Haematuria, Back Pain, Weight Loss, Urinary Incontinence, Urinary Retention, Fatigue, Bone Pain. (These signs and symptoms are often associated with prostate cancer due to the local effects of the tumour or metastatic disease.)

Docetaxel, Cabazitaxel, Abiraterone, Enzalutamide, Apalutamide, Darolutamide, Leuprorelin, Goserelin, Degarelix, Bicalutamide. (These medications are commonly used in the treatment of prostate cancer, including hormonal therapies and chemotherapy agents.)
New users of morphine are typically individuals experiencing moderate to severe pain, often due to trauma, surgery, or chronic conditions such as cancer.

New users of morphine are commonly seen in both primary care and hospital settings, and can be identified in various types of real-world healthcare data, including electronic health records and insurance data.
50 to 70 (Individuals typically present at ages between 50 and 70, as this age group often experiences conditions requiring significant pain management.)
40% to 60% (The proportion of males among new users of morphine is fairly balanced, reflecting the diverse range of conditions that require morphine for pain management.)
30% to 70% (Mortality among new users of morphine can vary widely depending on the underlying condition, with some individuals having a poor prognosis due to advanced illnesses such as cancer.)
0-2% with diagnosis_of_ankle_sprain, 10-20% with diagnosis_of_prostate_cancer

For diagnosis_of_ankle_sprain, new users of morphine may enter the cohort at the same time or shortly after (within days) due to acute pain management, while for diagnosis_of_prostate_cancer, new users of morphine may enter the cohort months to years after the cancer diagnosis due to progression of the disease requiring stronger pain management.

Lower back pain, major depressive disorder, essential (primary) hypertension, type 2 diabetes without complication, morbid obesity, anxiety disorder, chronic airway obstruction, not elsewhere classified, other diseases of lung, other chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. (These comorbidities are commonly seen among new users of morphine due to the prevalence of chronic pain and the need for pain management in these conditions.)

Pain, shortness of breath, cough, wheezing, chest pain, fatigue, oedema, expectoration, cough with sputum, abdominal distention. (These signs and symptoms are often associated with conditions that require morphine for pain management, such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and cancer.)

Paracetamol, Ibuprofen, Codeine, Gabapentin, Pregabalin, Amitriptyline, Naproxen, Diclofenac, Tramadol, Celecoxib. (These medications are commonly used for pain management and are often prescribed alongside morphine to manage various types of pain.)
